English[edit]

Alternative forms[edit]

Etymology[edit]

From Middle English wer, from Old English wer (â€œa male being, man, husband, heroâ€), from Proto-Germanic *weraz (â€œmanâ€), from Proto-Indo-European *wiHrÃ³s (â€œman, freemanâ€). Cognate with Middle High German wÃ«r (â€œmanâ€), Swedish vÃ¤rbror (â€œbrother-in-lawâ€), Norwegian verfader (â€œfather-in-lawâ€), Latin vir (â€œman, husbandâ€).

Noun[edit]

wer (plural wers)

  1. (obsolete) A man.
  2. (obsolete) Wergeld.

German[edit]

Etymology[edit]

From Proto-Germanic *hwaz, from Proto-Indo-European *kÊ·is. Related to wo.

Pronunciation[edit]

  • IPA(key): /veËÉÌ¯/, /vÉ›ÉÌ¯/
  • Audio
    		(file)
  • Homophone: Wehr
  • Rhymes: -eËÉÌ¯

Pronoun[edit]

wer

  1. (interrogative) who (what person or people)
    Wer hat das gesagt? â€“ Who said that?
  2. (interrogative, colloquial) what, which (one) (see usage notes)
  3. (relative) whoever, he who, someone who, the person who, anyone who (whatever person or persons)
    Wer eine Frage hat, kann sich jetzt melden.
    Whoever has a question, put up their hands now.
  4. (indefinite, colloquial) somebody, someone; anybody, anyone (an unspecified person)
    Da ist wer an der TÃ¼r. â€“ There's somebody at the door.

Usage notes[edit]

  • (what): In colloquial German, wer and its forms may be used in reference to things. This is often done when asking about a noun whose gender one knows to be masculine or feminine. For example: Kannst du mir mal den Dings rÃ¼bergeben? â€“ Wen? (â€œCould you pass me the thingamabob?â€ â€“ â€œPass what?â€) In this case, the interrogative mirrors the gender of the noun one asks about.
  • (someone): The colloquial wer meaning â€œsomeoneâ€ cannot usually be the first word in a main clause, because it could be misinterpreted as an interrogative in this position. The only exception is when it is followed by a nominalized adjective:
    Wer Neues ist in die Mannschaft gekommen. â€“ Someone new joined the team.

Inflection[edit]

  • N: wer
  • G: wessen â€“ obsolete, poetic: wes
  • D: wem
  • A: wen

Synonyms[edit]

  • (indefinite, colloquial): jemand, einer

Coordinate terms[edit]

  • was

Related terms[edit]

  • irgendwer
  • wer da
  • Werdaruf
  • Werfall
  • Wemfall
  • Wenfall

Etymology 1[edit]

From Proto-Germanic *weraz, from Proto-Indo-European *wiHrÃ³s (â€œfreemanâ€). Germanic cognates include Old Frisian, Old Saxon, Old High German wer, Old Norse verr, Gothic ğ…ğŒ°ğŒ¹ğ‚ (wair).
